original_title: Sri Lanka’s coconuts could get hammered by El Nino: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – A severe drought that would follow the excessive rain could impact the country’s coconut cultivation, Sri Lanka’s Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera, said.
“We will face severe drought conditions in the upcoming seasons, especially as the El Nino weather phenomenon develops,” Amaraweera said in a statement.

Local and international weather forecasts have predicted that the current El Nino situation may develop into a severe drought in the upcoming yala (minor) season of this year, with the possibility that crops, including coconut cultivation, in Sri Lanka will be negatively affected.
“We must take steps that will enable the coconut cultivation to face the drought: By digging pits to retain moisture in coconut plantations, as well as covering the roots of coconut trees with husk.”
“An acre of coconut land will need to have at least 16 specially prepared coconut pits. The technology for preparing these coconut pits is to be provided by the Coconut Cultivation Board.”
The government has allocated 300 million rupees for programs to protect coconut cultivations from El Nino weather effects, Amaraweera said, while 360,000 saplings are to be planted.
Amaraweera said officials of all institutions dealing with coconut have been instructed to implement a joint work plan to protect coconut cultivation in the island.

According to the Sri Lanka Export Development Board, coconut and coconut related products made up 6.11 percent of the country’s total exports, which showed a slight increase from the 6.4 percent in 2022. (Colombo/Jan8/2024)
